preface.para: SCENE Oliver's house; Duke Frederick's court; and the Forest of Arden.

section.title: SCENE I. Orchard of Oliver's house.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: As I remember, Adam, it was upon this fashion
bequeathed me by will but poor a thousand crowns,
and, as thou sayest, charged my brother, on his
blessing, to breed me well: and there begins my
sadness. My brother Jaques he keeps at school, and
report speaks goldenly of his profit: for my part,
he keeps me rustically at home, or, to speak more
properly, stays me here at home unkept; for call you
that keeping for a gentleman of my birth, that
differs not from the stalling of an ox? His horses
are bred better; for, besides that they are fair
with their feeding, they are taught their manage,
and to that end riders dearly hired: but I, his
brother, gain nothing under him but growth; for the
which his animals on his dunghills are as much
bound to him as I. Besides this nothing that he so
plentifully gives me, the something that nature gave
me his countenance seems to take from me: he lets
me feed with his hinds, bars me the place of a
brother, and, as much as in him lies, mines my
gentility with my education. This is it, Adam, that
grieves me; and the spirit of my father, which I
think is within me, begins to mutiny against this
servitude: I will no longer endure it, though yet I
know no wise remedy how to avoid it.

linegroup.speaker: ADAM
linegroup.line: Yonder comes my master, your brother.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Go apart, Adam, and thou shalt hear how he will
shake me up.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVER
linegroup.line: Now, sir! what make you here?

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Nothing: I am not taught to make any thing.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVER
linegroup.line: What mar you then, sir?

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Marry, sir, I am helping you to mar that which God
made, a poor unworthy brother of yours, with idleness.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVER
linegroup.line: Marry, sir, be better employed, and be naught awhile.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Shall I keep your hogs and eat husks with them?
What prodigal portion have I spent, that I should
come to such penury?

linegroup.speaker: OLIVER
linegroup.line: Know you where your are, sir?

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: O, sir, very well; here in your orchard.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVER
linegroup.line: Know you before whom, sir?

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Ay, better than him I am before knows me. I know
you are my eldest brother; and, in the gentle
condition of blood, you should so know me. The
courtesy of nations allows you my better, in that
you are the first-born; but the same tradition
takes not away my blood, were there twenty brothers
betwixt us: I have as much of my father in me as
you; albeit, I confess, your coming before me is
nearer to his reverence.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVER
linegroup.line: What, boy!

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Come, come, elder brother, you are too young in this.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVER
linegroup.line: Wilt thou lay hands on me, villain?

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: I am no villain; I am the youngest son of Sir
Rowland de Boys; he was my father, and he is thrice
a villain that says such a father begot villains.
Wert thou not my brother, I would not take this hand
from thy throat till this other had pulled out thy
tongue for saying so: thou hast railed on thyself.

linegroup.speaker: ADAM
linegroup.line: Sweet masters, be patient: for your father's
remembrance, be at accord.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVER
linegroup.line: Let me go, I say.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: I will not, till I please: you shall hear me. My
father charged you in his will to give me good
education: you have trained me like a peasant,
obscuring and hiding from me all gentleman-like
qualities. The spirit of my father grows strong in
me, and I will no longer endure it: therefore allow
me such exercises as may become a gentleman, or
give me the poor allottery my father left me by
testament; with that I will go buy my fortunes.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVER
linegroup.line: And what wilt thou do? beg, when that is spent?
Well, sir, get you in: I will not long be troubled
with you; you shall have some part of your will: I
pray you, leave me.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: I will no further offend you than becomes me for my good.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVER
linegroup.line: Get you with him, you old dog.

linegroup.speaker: ADAM
linegroup.line: Is 'old dog' my reward? Most true, I have lost my
teeth in your service. God be with my old master!
he would not have spoke such a word.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVER
linegroup.line: Is it even so? begin you to grow upon me? I will
physic your rankness, and yet give no thousand
crowns neither. Holla, Dennis!

linegroup.speaker: DENNIS
linegroup.line: Calls your worship?

linegroup.speaker: OLIVER
linegroup.line: Was not Charles, the duke's wrestler, here to speak with me?

linegroup.speaker: DENNIS
linegroup.line: So please you, he is here at the door and importunes
access to you.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVER
linegroup.line: Call him in.
'Twill be a good way; and to-morrow the wrestling is.

linegroup.speaker: CHARLES
linegroup.line: Good morrow to your worship.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVER
linegroup.line: Good Monsieur Charles, what's the new news at the
new court?

linegroup.speaker: CHARLES
linegroup.line: There's no news at the court, sir, but the old news:
that is, the old duke is banished by his younger
brother the new duke; and three or four loving lords
have put themselves into voluntary exile with him,
whose lands and revenues enrich the new duke;
therefore he gives them good leave to wander.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVER
linegroup.line: Can you tell if Rosalind, the duke's daughter, be
banished with her father?

linegroup.speaker: CHARLES
linegroup.line: O, no; for the duke's daughter, her cousin, so loves
her, being ever from their cradles bred together,
that she would have followed her exile, or have died
to stay behind her. She is at the court, and no
less beloved of her uncle than his own daughter; and
never two ladies loved as they do.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVER
linegroup.line: Where will the old duke live?

linegroup.speaker: CHARLES
linegroup.line: They say he is already in the forest of Arden, and
a many merry men with him; and there they live like
the old Robin Hood of England: they say many young
gentlemen flock to him every day, and fleet the time
carelessly, as they did in the golden world.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVER
linegroup.line: What, you wrestle to-morrow before the new duke?

linegroup.speaker: CHARLES
linegroup.line: Marry, do I, sir; and I came to acquaint you with a
matter. I am given, sir, secretly to understand
that your younger brother Orlando hath a disposition
to come in disguised against me to try a fall.
To-morrow, sir, I wrestle for my credit; and he that
escapes me without some broken limb shall acquit him
well. Your brother is but young and tender; and,
for your love, I would be loath to foil him, as I
must, for my own honour, if he come in: therefore,
out of my love to you, I came hither to acquaint you
withal, that either you might stay him from his
intendment or brook such disgrace well as he shall
run into, in that it is a thing of his own search
and altogether against my will.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVER
linegroup.line: Charles, I thank thee for thy love to me, which
thou shalt find I will most kindly requite. I had
myself notice of my brother's purpose herein and
have by underhand means laboured to dissuade him from
it, but he is resolute. I'll tell thee, Charles:
it is the stubbornest young fellow of France, full
of ambition, an envious emulator of every man's
good parts, a secret and villanous contriver against
me his natural brother: therefore use thy
discretion; I had as lief thou didst break his neck
as his finger. And thou wert best look to't; for if
thou dost him any slight disgrace or if he do not
mightily grace himself on thee, he will practise
against thee by poison, entrap thee by some
treacherous device and never leave thee till he
hath ta'en thy life by some indirect means or other;
for, I assure thee, and almost with tears I speak
it, there is not one so young and so villanous this
day living. I speak but brotherly of him; but
should I anatomize him to thee as he is, I must
blush and weep and thou must look pale and wonder.

linegroup.speaker: CHARLES
linegroup.line: I am heartily glad I came hither to you. If he come
to-morrow, I'll give him his payment: if ever he go
alone again, I'll never wrestle for prize more: and
so God keep your worship!

linegroup.speaker: OLIVER
linegroup.line: Farewell, good Charles.
Now will I stir this gamester: I hope I shall see
an end of him; for my soul, yet I know not why,
hates nothing more than he. Yet he's gentle, never
schooled and yet learned, full of noble device, of
all sorts enchantingly beloved, and indeed so much
in the heart of the world, and especially of my own
people, who best know him, that I am altogether
misprised: but it shall not be so long; this
wrestler shall clear all: nothing remains but that
I kindle the boy thither; which now I'll go about.

section.title: SCENE II. Lawn before the Duke's palace.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: I pray thee, Rosalind, sweet my coz, be merry.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Dear Celia, I show more mirth than I am mistress of;
and would you yet I were merrier? Unless you could
teach me to forget a banished father, you must not
learn me how to remember any extraordinary pleasure.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Herein I see thou lovest me not with the full weight
that I love thee. If my uncle, thy banished father,
had banished thy uncle, the duke my father, so thou
hadst been still with me, I could have taught my
love to take thy father for mine: so wouldst thou,
if the truth of thy love to me were so righteously
tempered as mine is to thee.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Well, I will forget the condition of my estate, to
rejoice in yours.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: You know my father hath no child but I, nor none is
like to have: and, truly, when he dies, thou shalt
be his heir, for what he hath taken away from thy
father perforce, I will render thee again in
affection; by mine honour, I will; and when I break
that oath, let me turn monster: therefore, my
sweet Rose, my dear Rose, be merry.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: From henceforth I will, coz, and devise sports. Let
me see; what think you of falling in love?

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Marry, I prithee, do, to make sport withal: but
love no man in good earnest; nor no further in sport
neither than with safety of a pure blush thou mayst
in honour come off again.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: What shall be our sport, then?

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Let us sit and mock the good housewife Fortune from
her wheel, that her gifts may henceforth be bestowed equally.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: I would we could do so, for her benefits are
mightily misplaced, and the bountiful blind woman
doth most mistake in her gifts to women.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: 'Tis true; for those that she makes fair she scarce
makes honest, and those that she makes honest she
makes very ill-favouredly.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Nay, now thou goest from Fortune's office to
Nature's: Fortune reigns in gifts of the world,
not in the lineaments of Nature.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: No? when Nature hath made a fair creature, may she
not by Fortune fall into the fire? Though Nature
hath given us wit to flout at Fortune, hath not
Fortune sent in this fool to cut off the argument?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Indeed, there is Fortune too hard for Nature, when
Fortune makes Nature's natural the cutter-off of
Nature's wit.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Peradventure this is not Fortune's work neither, but
Nature's; who perceiveth our natural wits too dull
to reason of such goddesses and hath sent this
natural for our whetstone; for always the dulness of
the fool is the whetstone of the wits. How now,
wit! whither wander you?

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: Mistress, you must come away to your father.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Were you made the messenger?

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: No, by mine honour, but I was bid to come for you.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Where learned you that oath, fool?

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: Of a certain knight that swore by his honour they
were good pancakes and swore by his honour the
mustard was naught: now I'll stand to it, the
pancakes were naught and the mustard was good, and
yet was not the knight forsworn.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: How prove you that, in the great heap of your
knowledge?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Ay, marry, now unmuzzle your wisdom.

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: Stand you both forth now: stroke your chins, and
swear by your beards that I am a knave.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: By our beards, if we had them, thou art.

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: By my knavery, if I had it, then I were; but if you
swear by that that is not, you are not forsworn: no
more was this knight swearing by his honour, for he
never had any; or if he had, he had sworn it away
before ever he saw those pancakes or that mustard.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Prithee, who is't that thou meanest?

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: One that old Frederick, your father, loves.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: My father's love is enough to honour him: enough!
speak no more of him; you'll be whipped for taxation
one of these days.

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: The more pity, that fools may not speak wisely what
wise men do foolishly.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: By my troth, thou sayest true; for since the little
wit that fools have was silenced, the little foolery
that wise men have makes a great show. Here comes
Monsieur Le Beau.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: With his mouth full of news.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Which he will put on us, as pigeons feed their young.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Then shall we be news-crammed.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: All the better; we shall be the more marketable.
Bon jour, Monsieur Le Beau: what's the news?

linegroup.speaker: LE BEAU
linegroup.line: Fair princess, you have lost much good sport.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Sport! of what colour?

linegroup.speaker: LE BEAU
linegroup.line: What colour, madam! how shall I answer you?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: As wit and fortune will.

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: Or as the Destinies decree.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Well said: that was laid on with a trowel.

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: Nay, if I keep not my rank,--

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Thou losest thy old smell.

linegroup.speaker: LE BEAU
linegroup.line: You amaze me, ladies: I would have told you of good
wrestling, which you have lost the sight of.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: You tell us the manner of the wrestling.

linegroup.speaker: LE BEAU
linegroup.line: I will tell you the beginning; and, if it please
your ladyships, you may see the end; for the best is
yet to do; and here, where you are, they are coming
to perform it.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Well, the beginning, that is dead and buried.

linegroup.speaker: LE BEAU
linegroup.line: There comes an old man and his three sons,--

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: I could match this beginning with an old tale.

linegroup.speaker: LE BEAU
linegroup.line: Three proper young men, of excellent growth and presence.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: With bills on their necks, 'Be it known unto all men
by these presents.'

linegroup.speaker: LE BEAU
linegroup.line: The eldest of the three wrestled with Charles, the
duke's wrestler; which Charles in a moment threw him
and broke three of his ribs, that there is little
hope of life in him: so he served the second, and
so the third. Yonder they lie; the poor old man,
their father, making such pitiful dole over them
that all the beholders take his part with weeping.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Alas!

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: But what is the sport, monsieur, that the ladies
have lost?

linegroup.speaker: LE BEAU
linegroup.line: Why, this that I speak of.

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: Thus men may grow wiser every day: it is the first
time that ever I heard breaking of ribs was sport
for ladies.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Or I, I promise thee.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: But is there any else longs to see this broken music
in his sides? is there yet another dotes upon
rib-breaking? Shall we see this wrestling, cousin?

linegroup.speaker: LE BEAU
linegroup.line: You must, if you stay here; for here is the place
appointed for the wrestling, and they are ready to
perform it.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Yonder, sure, they are coming: let us now stay and see it.

section.para: Flourish. Enter DUKE FREDERICK, Lords, ORLANDO, CHARLES, and Attendants

linegroup.speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
linegroup.line: Come on: since the youth will not be entreated, his
own peril on his forwardness.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Is yonder the man?

linegroup.speaker: LE BEAU
linegroup.line: Even he, madam.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Alas, he is too young! yet he looks successfully.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
linegroup.line: How now, daughter and cousin! are you crept hither
to see the wrestling?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Ay, my liege, so please you give us leave.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
linegroup.line: You will take little delight in it, I can tell you;
there is such odds in the man. In pity of the
challenger's youth I would fain dissuade him, but he
will not be entreated. Speak to him, ladies; see if
you can move him.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Call him hither, good Monsieur Le Beau.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
linegroup.line: Do so: I'll not be by.

linegroup.speaker: LE BEAU
linegroup.line: Monsieur the challenger, the princesses call for you.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: I attend them with all respect and duty.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Young man, have you challenged Charles the wrestler?

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: No, fair princess; he is the general challenger: I
come but in, as others do, to try with him the
strength of my youth.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Young gentleman, your spirits are too bold for your
years. You have seen cruel proof of this man's
strength: if you saw yourself with your eyes or
knew yourself with your judgment, the fear of your
adventure would counsel you to a more equal
enterprise. We pray you, for your own sake, to
embrace your own safety and give over this attempt.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Do, young sir; your reputation shall not therefore
be misprised: we will make it our suit to the duke
that the wrestling might not go forward.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: I beseech you, punish me not with your hard
thoughts; wherein I confess me much guilty, to deny
so fair and excellent ladies any thing. But let
your fair eyes and gentle wishes go with me to my
trial: wherein if I be foiled, there is but one
shamed that was never gracious; if killed, but one
dead that was willing to be so: I shall do my
friends no wrong, for I have none to lament me, the
world no injury, for in it I have nothing; only in
the world I fill up a place, which may be better
supplied when I have made it empty.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: The little strength that I have, I would it were with you.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: And mine, to eke out hers.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Fare you well: pray heaven I be deceived in you!

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Your heart's desires be with you!

linegroup.speaker: CHARLES
linegroup.line: Come, where is this young gallant that is so
desirous to lie with his mother earth?

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Ready, sir; but his will hath in it a more modest working.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
linegroup.line: You shall try but one fall.

linegroup.speaker: CHARLES
linegroup.line: No, I warrant your grace, you shall not entreat him
to a second, that have so mightily persuaded him
from a first.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: An you mean to mock me after, you should not have
mocked me before: but come your ways.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Now Hercules be thy speed, young man!

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: I would I were invisible, to catch the strong
fellow by the leg.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: O excellent young man!

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: If I had a thunderbolt in mine eye, I can tell who
should down.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
linegroup.line: No more, no more.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Yes, I beseech your grace: I am not yet well breathed.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
linegroup.line: How dost thou, Charles?

linegroup.speaker: LE BEAU
linegroup.line: He cannot speak, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
linegroup.line: Bear him away. What is thy name, young man?

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Orlando, my liege; the youngest son of Sir Rowland de Boys.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
linegroup.line: I would thou hadst been son to some man else:
The world esteem'd thy father honourable,
But I did find him still mine enemy:
Thou shouldst have better pleased me with this deed,
Hadst thou descended from another house.
But fare thee well; thou art a gallant youth:
I would thou hadst told me of another father.

section.para: Exeunt DUKE FREDERICK, train, and LE BEAU

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Were I my father, coz, would I do this?

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: I am more proud to be Sir Rowland's son,
His youngest son; and would not change that calling,
To be adopted heir to Frederick.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: My father loved Sir Rowland as his soul,
And all the world was of my father's mind:
Had I before known this young man his son,
I should have given him tears unto entreaties,
Ere he should thus have ventured.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Gentle cousin,
Let us go thank him and encourage him:
My father's rough and envious disposition
Sticks me at heart. Sir, you have well deserved:
If you do keep your promises in love
But justly, as you have exceeded all promise,
Your mistress shall be happy.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Gentleman,
linegroup.para: Giving him a chain from her neck
linegroup.line: Wear this for me, one out of suits with fortune,
That could give more, but that her hand lacks means.
Shall we go, coz?

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Ay. Fare you well, fair gentleman.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Can I not say, I thank you? My better parts
Are all thrown down, and that which here stands up
Is but a quintain, a mere lifeless block.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: He calls us back: my pride fell with my fortunes;
I'll ask him what he would. Did you call, sir?
Sir, you have wrestled well and overthrown
More than your enemies.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Will you go, coz?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Have with you. Fare you well.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: What passion hangs these weights upon my tongue?
I cannot speak to her, yet she urged conference.
O poor Orlando, thou art overthrown!
Or Charles or something weaker masters thee.

linegroup.speaker: LE BEAU
linegroup.line: Good sir, I do in friendship counsel you
To leave this place. Albeit you have deserved
High commendation, true applause and love,
Yet such is now the duke's condition
That he misconstrues all that you have done.
The duke is humorous; what he is indeed,
More suits you to conceive than I to speak of.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: I thank you, sir: and, pray you, tell me this:
Which of the two was daughter of the duke
That here was at the wrestling?

linegroup.speaker: LE BEAU
linegroup.line: Neither his daughter, if we judge by manners;
But yet indeed the lesser is his daughter
The other is daughter to the banish'd duke,
And here detain'd by her usurping uncle,
To keep his daughter company; whose loves
Are dearer than the natural bond of sisters.
But I can tell you that of late this duke
Hath ta'en displeasure 'gainst his gentle niece,
Grounded upon no other argument
But that the people praise her for her virtues
And pity her for her good father's sake;
And, on my life, his malice 'gainst the lady
Will suddenly break forth. Sir, fare you well:
Hereafter, in a better world than this,
I shall desire more love and knowledge of you.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: I rest much bounden to you: fare you well.
Thus must I from the smoke into the smother;
From tyrant duke unto a tyrant brother:
But heavenly Rosalind!

section.title: SCENE III. A room in the palace.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Why, cousin! why, Rosalind! Cupid have mercy! not a word?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Not one to throw at a dog.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: No, thy words are too precious to be cast away upon
curs; throw some of them at me; come, lame me with reasons.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Then there were two cousins laid up; when the one
should be lamed with reasons and the other mad
without any.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: But is all this for your father?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: No, some of it is for my child's father. O, how
full of briers is this working-day world!

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: They are but burs, cousin, thrown upon thee in
holiday foolery: if we walk not in the trodden
paths our very petticoats will catch them.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: I could shake them off my coat: these burs are in my heart.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Hem them away.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: I would try, if I could cry 'hem' and have him.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Come, come, wrestle with thy affections.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: O, they take the part of a better wrestler than myself!

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: O, a good wish upon you! you will try in time, in
despite of a fall. But, turning these jests out of
service, let us talk in good earnest: is it
possible, on such a sudden, you should fall into so
strong a liking with old Sir Rowland's youngest son?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: The duke my father loved his father dearly.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Doth it therefore ensue that you should love his son
dearly? By this kind of chase, I should hate him,
for my father hated his father dearly; yet I hate
not Orlando.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: No, faith, hate him not, for my sake.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Why should I not? doth he not deserve well?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Let me love him for that, and do you love him
because I do. Look, here comes the duke.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: With his eyes full of anger.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
linegroup.line: Mistress, dispatch you with your safest haste
And get you from our court.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Me, uncle?

linegroup.speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
linegroup.line: You, cousin
Within these ten days if that thou be'st found
So near our public court as twenty miles,
Thou diest for it.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: I do beseech your grace,
Let me the knowledge of my fault bear with me:
If with myself I hold intelligence
Or have acquaintance with mine own desires,
If that I do not dream or be not frantic,--
As I do trust I am not--then, dear uncle,
Never so much as in a thought unborn
Did I offend your highness.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
linegroup.line: Thus do all traitors:
If their purgation did consist in words,
They are as innocent as grace itself:
Let it suffice thee that I trust thee not.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Yet your mistrust cannot make me a traitor:
Tell me whereon the likelihood depends.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
linegroup.line: Thou art thy father's daughter; there's enough.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: So was I when your highness took his dukedom;
So was I when your highness banish'd him:
Treason is not inherited, my lord;
Or, if we did derive it from our friends,
What's that to me? my father was no traitor:
Then, good my liege, mistake me not so much
To think my poverty is treacherous.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Dear sovereign, hear me speak.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
linegroup.line: Ay, Celia; we stay'd her for your sake,
Else had she with her father ranged along.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: I did not then entreat to have her stay;
It was your pleasure and your own remorse:
I was too young that time to value her;
But now I know her: if she be a traitor,
Why so am I; we still have slept together,
Rose at an instant, learn'd, play'd, eat together,
And wheresoever we went, like Juno's swans,
Still we went coupled and inseparable.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
linegroup.line: She is too subtle for thee; and her smoothness,
Her very silence and her patience
Speak to the people, and they pity her.
Thou art a fool: she robs thee of thy name;
And thou wilt show more bright and seem more virtuous
When she is gone. Then open not thy lips:
Firm and irrevocable is my doom
Which I have pass'd upon her; she is banish'd.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Pronounce that sentence then on me, my liege:
I cannot live out of her company.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
linegroup.line: You are a fool. You, niece, provide yourself:
If you outstay the time, upon mine honour,
And in the greatness of my word, you die.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: O my poor Rosalind, whither wilt thou go?
Wilt thou change fathers? I will give thee mine.
I charge thee, be not thou more grieved than I am.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: I have more cause.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Thou hast not, cousin;
Prithee be cheerful: know'st thou not, the duke
Hath banish'd me, his daughter?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: That he hath not.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: No, hath not? Rosalind lacks then the love
Which teacheth thee that thou and I am one:
Shall we be sunder'd? shall we part, sweet girl?
No: let my father seek another heir.
Therefore devise with me how we may fly,
Whither to go and what to bear with us;
And do not seek to take your change upon you,
To bear your griefs yourself and leave me out;
For, by this heaven, now at our sorrows pale,
Say what thou canst, I'll go along with thee.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Why, whither shall we go?

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: To seek my uncle in the forest of Arden.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Alas, what danger will it be to us,
Maids as we are, to travel forth so far!
Beauty provoketh thieves sooner than gold.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: I'll put myself in poor and mean attire
And with a kind of umber smirch my face;
The like do you: so shall we pass along
And never stir assailants.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Were it not better,
Because that I am more than common tall,
That I did suit me all points like a man?
A gallant curtle-axe upon my thigh,
A boar-spear in my hand; and--in my heart
Lie there what hidden woman's fear there will--
We'll have a swashing and a martial outside,
As many other mannish cowards have
That do outface it with their semblances.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: What shall I call thee when thou art a man?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: I'll have no worse a name than Jove's own page;
And therefore look you call me Ganymede.
But what will you be call'd?

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Something that hath a reference to my state
No longer Celia, but Aliena.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: But, cousin, what if we assay'd to steal
The clownish fool out of your father's court?
Would he not be a comfort to our travel?

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: He'll go along o'er the wide world with me;
Leave me alone to woo him. Let's away,
And get our jewels and our wealth together,
Devise the fittest time and safest way
To hide us from pursuit that will be made
After my flight. Now go we in content
To liberty and not to banishment.

section.title: SCENE I. The Forest of Arden.
section.para: Enter DUKE SENIOR, AMIENS, and two or three Lords, like foresters

linegroup.speaker: DUKE SENIOR
linegroup.line: Now, my co-mates and brothers in exile,
Hath not old custom made this life more sweet
Than that of painted pomp? Are not these woods
More free from peril than the envious court?
Here feel we but the penalty of Adam,
The seasons' difference, as the icy fang
And churlish chiding of the winter's wind,
Which, when it bites and blows upon my body,
Even till I shrink with cold, I smile and say
'This is no flattery: these are counsellors
That feelingly persuade me what I am.'
Sweet are the uses of adversity,
Which, like the toad, ugly and venomous,
Wears yet a precious jewel in his head;
And this our life exempt from public haunt
Finds tongues in trees, books in the running brooks,
Sermons in stones and good in every thing.
I would not change it.

linegroup.speaker: AMIENS
linegroup.line: Happy is your grace,
That can translate the stubbornness of fortune
Into so quiet and so sweet a style.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE SENIOR
linegroup.line: Come, shall we go and kill us venison?
And yet it irks me the poor dappled fools,
Being native burghers of this desert city,
Should in their own confines with forked heads
Have their round haunches gored.

linegroup.speaker: First Lord
linegroup.line: Indeed, my lord,
The melancholy Jaques grieves at that,
And, in that kind, swears you do more usurp
Than doth your brother that hath banish'd you.
To-day my Lord of Amiens and myself
Did steal behind him as he lay along
Under an oak whose antique root peeps out
Upon the brook that brawls along this wood:
To the which place a poor sequester'd stag,
That from the hunter's aim had ta'en a hurt,
Did come to languish, and indeed, my lord,
The wretched animal heaved forth such groans
That their discharge did stretch his leathern coat
Almost to bursting, and the big round tears
Coursed one another down his innocent nose
In piteous chase; and thus the hairy fool
Much marked of the melancholy Jaques,
Stood on the extremest verge of the swift brook,
Augmenting it with tears.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE SENIOR
linegroup.line: But what said Jaques?
Did he not moralize this spectacle?

linegroup.speaker: First Lord
linegroup.line: O, yes, into a thousand similes.
First, for his weeping into the needless stream;
'Poor deer,' quoth he, 'thou makest a testament
As worldlings do, giving thy sum of more
To that which had too much:' then, being there alone,
Left and abandon'd of his velvet friends,
''Tis right:' quoth he; 'thus misery doth part
The flux of company:' anon a careless herd,
Full of the pasture, jumps along by him
And never stays to greet him; 'Ay' quoth Jaques,
'Sweep on, you fat and greasy citizens;
'Tis just the fashion: wherefore do you look
Upon that poor and broken bankrupt there?'
Thus most invectively he pierceth through
The body of the country, city, court,
Yea, and of this our life, swearing that we
Are mere usurpers, tyrants and what's worse,
To fright the animals and to kill them up
In their assign'd and native dwelling-place.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE SENIOR
linegroup.line: And did you leave him in this contemplation?

linegroup.speaker: Second Lord
linegroup.line: We did, my lord, weeping and commenting
Upon the sobbing deer.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE SENIOR
linegroup.line: Show me the place:
I love to cope him in these sullen fits,
For then he's full of matter.

linegroup.speaker: First Lord
linegroup.line: I'll bring you to him straight.

section.title: SCENE II. A room in the palace.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
linegroup.line: Can it be possible that no man saw them?
It cannot be: some villains of my court
Are of consent and sufferance in this.

linegroup.speaker: First Lord
linegroup.line: I cannot hear of any that did see her.
The ladies, her attendants of her chamber,
Saw her abed, and in the morning early
They found the bed untreasured of their mistress.

linegroup.speaker: Second Lord
linegroup.line: My lord, the roynish clown, at whom so oft
Your grace was wont to laugh, is also missing.
Hisperia, the princess' gentlewoman,
Confesses that she secretly o'erheard
Your daughter and her cousin much commend
The parts and graces of the wrestler
That did but lately foil the sinewy Charles;
And she believes, wherever they are gone,
That youth is surely in their company.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
linegroup.line: Send to his brother; fetch that gallant hither;
If he be absent, bring his brother to me;
I'll make him find him: do this suddenly,
And let not search and inquisition quail
To bring again these foolish runaways.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Who's there?

linegroup.speaker: ADAM
linegroup.line: What, my young master? O, my gentle master!
O my sweet master! O you memory
Of old Sir Rowland! why, what make you here?
Why are you virtuous? why do people love you?
And wherefore are you gentle, strong and valiant?
Why would you be so fond to overcome
The bonny priser of the humorous duke?
Your praise is come too swiftly home before you.
Know you not, master, to some kind of men
Their graces serve them but as enemies?
No more do yours: your virtues, gentle master,
Are sanctified and holy traitors to you.
O, what a world is this, when what is comely
Envenoms him that bears it!

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Why, what's the matter?

linegroup.speaker: ADAM
linegroup.line: O unhappy youth!
Come not within these doors; within this roof
The enemy of all your graces lives:
Your brother--no, no brother; yet the son--
Yet not the son, I will not call him son
Of him I was about to call his father--
Hath heard your praises, and this night he means
To burn the lodging where you use to lie
And you within it: if he fail of that,
He will have other means to cut you off.
I overheard him and his practises.
This is no place; this house is but a butchery:
Abhor it, fear it, do not enter it.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Why, whither, Adam, wouldst thou have me go?

linegroup.speaker: ADAM
linegroup.line: No matter whither, so you come not here.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: What, wouldst thou have me go and beg my food?
Or with a base and boisterous sword enforce
A thievish living on the common road?
This I must do, or know not what to do:
Yet this I will not do, do how I can;
I rather will subject me to the malice
Of a diverted blood and bloody brother.

linegroup.speaker: ADAM
linegroup.line: But do not so. I have five hundred crowns,
The thrifty hire I saved under your father,
Which I did store to be my foster-nurse
When service should in my old limbs lie lame
And unregarded age in corners thrown:
Take that, and He that doth the ravens feed,
Yea, providently caters for the sparrow,
Be comfort to my age! Here is the gold;
And all this I give you. Let me be your servant:
Though I look old, yet I am strong and lusty;
For in my youth I never did apply
Hot and rebellious liquors in my blood,
Nor did not with unbashful forehead woo
The means of weakness and debility;
Therefore my age is as a lusty winter,
Frosty, but kindly: let me go with you;
I'll do the service of a younger man
In all your business and necessities.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: O good old man, how well in thee appears
The constant service of the antique world,
When service sweat for duty, not for meed!
Thou art not for the fashion of these times,
Where none will sweat but for promotion,
And having that, do choke their service up
Even with the having: it is not so with thee.
But, poor old man, thou prunest a rotten tree,
That cannot so much as a blossom yield
In lieu of all thy pains and husbandry
But come thy ways; well go along together,
And ere we have thy youthful wages spent,
We'll light upon some settled low content.

linegroup.speaker: ADAM
linegroup.line: Master, go on, and I will follow thee,
To the last gasp, with truth and loyalty.
From seventeen years till now almost fourscore
Here lived I, but now live here no more.
At seventeen years many their fortunes seek;
But at fourscore it is too late a week:
Yet fortune cannot recompense me better
Than to die well and not my master's debtor.

section.title: SCENE IV. The Forest of Arden.
section.para: Enter ROSALIND for Ganymede, CELIA for Aliena, and TOUCHSTONE

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: O Jupiter, how weary are my spirits!

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: I care not for my spirits, if my legs were not weary.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: I could find in my heart to disgrace my man's
apparel and to cry like a woman; but I must comfort
the weaker vessel, as doublet and hose ought to show
itself courageous to petticoat: therefore courage,
good Aliena!

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: I pray you, bear with me; I cannot go no further.

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: For my part, I had rather bear with you than bear
you; yet I should bear no cross if I did bear you,
for I think you have no money in your purse.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Well, this is the forest of Arden.

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: Ay, now am I in Arden; the more fool I; when I was
at home, I was in a better place: but travellers
must be content.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Ay, be so, good Touchstone.
Look you, who comes here; a young man and an old in
solemn talk.

linegroup.speaker: CORIN
linegroup.line: That is the way to make her scorn you still.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIUS
linegroup.line: O Corin, that thou knew'st how I do love her!

linegroup.speaker: CORIN
linegroup.line: I partly guess; for I have loved ere now.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIUS
linegroup.line: No, Corin, being old, thou canst not guess,
Though in thy youth thou wast as true a lover
As ever sigh'd upon a midnight pillow:
But if thy love were ever like to mine--
As sure I think did never man love so--
How many actions most ridiculous
Hast thou been drawn to by thy fantasy?

linegroup.speaker: CORIN
linegroup.line: Into a thousand that I have forgotten.

linegroup.speaker: SILVIUS
linegroup.line: O, thou didst then ne'er love so heartily!
If thou remember'st not the slightest folly
That ever love did make thee run into,
Thou hast not loved:
Or if thou hast not sat as I do now,
Wearying thy hearer in thy mistress' praise,
Thou hast not loved:
Or if thou hast not broke from company
Abruptly, as my passion now makes me,
Thou hast not loved.
O Phebe, Phebe, Phebe!

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Alas, poor shepherd! searching of thy wound,
I have by hard adventure found mine own.

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: And I mine. I remember, when I was in love I broke
my sword upon a stone and bid him take that for
coming a-night to Jane Smile; and I remember the
kissing of her batlet and the cow's dugs that her
pretty chopt hands had milked; and I remember the
wooing of a peascod instead of her, from whom I took
two cods and, giving her them again, said with
weeping tears 'Wear these for my sake.' We that are
true lovers run into strange capers; but as all is
mortal in nature, so is all nature in love mortal in folly.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Thou speakest wiser than thou art ware of.

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: Nay, I shall ne'er be ware of mine own wit till I
break my shins against it.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Jove, Jove! this shepherd's passion
Is much upon my fashion.

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: And mine; but it grows something stale with me.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: I pray you, one of you question yond man
If he for gold will give us any food:
I faint almost to death.

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: Holla, you clown!

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Peace, fool: he's not thy kinsman.

linegroup.speaker: CORIN
linegroup.line: Who calls?

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: Your betters, sir.

linegroup.speaker: CORIN
linegroup.line: Else are they very wretched.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Peace, I say. Good even to you, friend.

linegroup.speaker: CORIN
linegroup.line: And to you, gentle sir, and to you all.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: I prithee, shepherd, if that love or gold
Can in this desert place buy entertainment,
Bring us where we may rest ourselves and feed:
Here's a young maid with travel much oppress'd
And faints for succor.

linegroup.speaker: CORIN
linegroup.line: Fair sir, I pity her
And wish, for her sake more than for mine own,
My fortunes were more able to relieve her;
But I am shepherd to another man
And do not shear the fleeces that I graze:
My master is of churlish disposition
And little recks to find the way to heaven
By doing deeds of hospitality:
Besides, his cote, his flocks and bounds of feed
Are now on sale, and at our sheepcote now,
By reason of his absence, there is nothing
That you will feed on; but what is, come see.
And in my voice most welcome shall you be.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: What is he that shall buy his flock and pasture?

linegroup.speaker: CORIN
linegroup.line: That young swain that you saw here but erewhile,
That little cares for buying any thing.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: I pray thee, if it stand with honesty,
Buy thou the cottage, pasture and the flock,
And thou shalt have to pay for it of us.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: And we will mend thy wages. I like this place.
And willingly could waste my time in it.

linegroup.speaker: CORIN
linegroup.line: Assuredly the thing is to be sold:
Go with me: if you like upon report
The soil, the profit and this kind of life,
I will your very faithful feeder be
And buy it with your gold right suddenly.

linegroup.speaker: AMIENS
linegroup.line: Under the greenwood tree
Who loves to lie with me,
And turn his merry note
Unto the sweet bird's throat,
Come hither, come hither, come hither:
Here shall he see No enemy
But winter and rough weather.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: More, more, I prithee, more.

linegroup.speaker: AMIENS
linegroup.line: It will make you melancholy, Monsieur Jaques.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: I thank it. More, I prithee, more. I can suck
melancholy out of a song, as a weasel sucks eggs.
More, I prithee, more.

linegroup.speaker: AMIENS
linegroup.line: My voice is ragged: I know I cannot please you.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: I do not desire you to please me; I do desire you to
sing. Come, more; another stanzo: call you 'em stanzos?

linegroup.speaker: AMIENS
linegroup.line: What you will, Monsieur Jaques.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: Nay, I care not for their names; they owe me
nothing. Will you sing?

linegroup.speaker: AMIENS
linegroup.line: More at your request than to please myself.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: Well then, if ever I thank any man, I'll thank you;
but that they call compliment is like the encounter
of two dog-apes, and when a man thanks me heartily,
methinks I have given him a penny and he renders me
the beggarly thanks. Come, sing; and you that will
not, hold your tongues.

linegroup.speaker: AMIENS
linegroup.line: Well, I'll end the song. Sirs, cover the while; the
duke will drink under this tree. He hath been all
this day to look you.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: And I have been all this day to avoid him. He is
too disputable for my company: I think of as many
matters as he, but I give heaven thanks and make no
boast of them. Come, warble, come.
Who doth ambition shun
And loves to live i' the sun,
Seeking the food he eats
And pleased with what he gets,
Come hither, come hither, come hither:
Here shall he see No enemy
But winter and rough weather.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: I'll give you a verse to this note that I made
yesterday in despite of my invention.

linegroup.speaker: AMIENS
linegroup.line: And I'll sing it.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: Thus it goes:--
If it do come to pass
That any man turn ass,
Leaving his wealth and ease,
A stubborn will to please,
Ducdame, ducdame, ducdame:
Here shall he see
Gross fools as he,
An if he will come to me.

linegroup.speaker: AMIENS
linegroup.line: What's that 'ducdame'?

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: 'Tis a Greek invocation, to call fools into a
circle. I'll go sleep, if I can; if I cannot, I'll
rail against all the first-born of Egypt.

linegroup.speaker: AMIENS
linegroup.line: And I'll go seek the duke: his banquet is prepared.

linegroup.speaker: ADAM
linegroup.line: Dear master, I can go no further. O, I die for food!
Here lie I down, and measure out my grave. Farewell,
kind master.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Why, how now, Adam! no greater heart in thee? Live
a little; comfort a little; cheer thyself a little.
If this uncouth forest yield any thing savage, I
will either be food for it or bring it for food to
thee. Thy conceit is nearer death than thy powers.
For my sake be comfortable; hold death awhile at
the arm's end: I will here be with thee presently;
and if I bring thee not something to eat, I will
give thee leave to die: but if thou diest before I
come, thou art a mocker of my labour. Well said!
thou lookest cheerly, and I'll be with thee quickly.
Yet thou liest in the bleak air: come, I will bear
thee to some shelter; and thou shalt not die for
lack of a dinner, if there live any thing in this
desert. Cheerly, good Adam!

section.title: SCENE VII. The forest.
section.para: A table set out. Enter DUKE SENIOR, AMIENS, and Lords like outlaws

linegroup.speaker: DUKE SENIOR
linegroup.line: I think he be transform'd into a beast;
For I can no where find him like a man.

linegroup.speaker: First Lord
linegroup.line: My lord, he is but even now gone hence:
Here was he merry, hearing of a song.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE SENIOR
linegroup.line: If he, compact of jars, grow musical,
We shall have shortly discord in the spheres.
Go, seek him: tell him I would speak with him.

linegroup.speaker: First Lord
linegroup.line: He saves my labour by his own approach.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE SENIOR
linegroup.line: Why, how now, monsieur! what a life is this,
That your poor friends must woo your company?
What, you look merrily!

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: A fool, a fool! I met a fool i' the forest,
A motley fool; a miserable world!
As I do live by food, I met a fool
Who laid him down and bask'd him in the sun,
And rail'd on Lady Fortune in good terms,
In good set terms and yet a motley fool.
'Good morrow, fool,' quoth I. 'No, sir,' quoth he,
'Call me not fool till heaven hath sent me fortune:'
And then he drew a dial from his poke,
And, looking on it with lack-lustre eye,
Says very wisely, 'It is ten o'clock:
Thus we may see,' quoth he, 'how the world wags:
'Tis but an hour ago since it was nine,
And after one hour more 'twill be eleven;
And so, from hour to hour, we ripe and ripe,
And then, from hour to hour, we rot and rot;
And thereby hangs a tale.' When I did hear
The motley fool thus moral on the time,
My lungs began to crow like chanticleer,
That fools should be so deep-contemplative,
And I did laugh sans intermission
An hour by his dial. O noble fool!
A worthy fool! Motley's the only wear.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE SENIOR
linegroup.line: What fool is this?

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: O worthy fool! One that hath been a courtier,
And says, if ladies be but young and fair,
They have the gift to know it: and in his brain,
Which is as dry as the remainder biscuit
After a voyage, he hath strange places cramm'd
With observation, the which he vents
In mangled forms. O that I were a fool!
I am ambitious for a motley coat.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE SENIOR
linegroup.line: Thou shalt have one.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: It is my only suit;
Provided that you weed your better judgments
Of all opinion that grows rank in them
That I am wise. I must have liberty
Withal, as large a charter as the wind,
To blow on whom I please; for so fools have;
And they that are most galled with my folly,
They most must laugh. And why, sir, must they so?
The 'why' is plain as way to parish church:
He that a fool doth very wisely hit
Doth very foolishly, although he smart,
Not to seem senseless of the bob: if not,
The wise man's folly is anatomized
Even by the squandering glances of the fool.
Invest me in my motley; give me leave
To speak my mind, and I will through and through
Cleanse the foul body of the infected world,
If they will patiently receive my medicine.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE SENIOR
linegroup.line: Fie on thee! I can tell what thou wouldst do.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: What, for a counter, would I do but good?

linegroup.speaker: DUKE SENIOR
linegroup.line: Most mischievous foul sin, in chiding sin:
For thou thyself hast been a libertine,
As sensual as the brutish sting itself;
And all the embossed sores and headed evils,
That thou with licence of free foot hast caught,
Wouldst thou disgorge into the general world.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: Why, who cries out on pride,
That can therein tax any private party?
Doth it not flow as hugely as the sea,
Till that the weary very means do ebb?
What woman in the city do I name,
When that I say the city-woman bears
The cost of princes on unworthy shoulders?
Who can come in and say that I mean her,
When such a one as she such is her neighbour?
Or what is he of basest function
That says his bravery is not of my cost,
Thinking that I mean him, but therein suits
His folly to the mettle of my speech?
There then; how then? what then? Let me see wherein
My tongue hath wrong'd him: if it do him right,
Then he hath wrong'd himself; if he be free,
Why then my taxing like a wild-goose flies,
Unclaim'd of any man. But who comes here?

section.para: Enter ORLANDO, with his sword drawn

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Forbear, and eat no more.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: Why, I have eat none yet.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Nor shalt not, till necessity be served.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: Of what kind should this cock come of?

linegroup.speaker: DUKE SENIOR
linegroup.line: Art thou thus bolden'd, man, by thy distress,
Or else a rude despiser of good manners,
That in civility thou seem'st so empty?

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: You touch'd my vein at first: the thorny point
Of bare distress hath ta'en from me the show
Of smooth civility: yet am I inland bred
And know some nurture. But forbear, I say:
He dies that touches any of this fruit
Till I and my affairs are answered.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: An you will not be answered with reason, I must die.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE SENIOR
linegroup.line: What would you have? Your gentleness shall force
More than your force move us to gentleness.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: I almost die for food; and let me have it.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE SENIOR
linegroup.line: Sit down and feed, and welcome to our table.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Speak you so gently? Pardon me, I pray you:
I thought that all things had been savage here;
And therefore put I on the countenance
Of stern commandment. But whate'er you are
That in this desert inaccessible,
Under the shade of melancholy boughs,
Lose and neglect the creeping hours of time
If ever you have look'd on better days,
If ever been where bells have knoll'd to church,
If ever sat at any good man's feast,
If ever from your eyelids wiped a tear
And know what 'tis to pity and be pitied,
Let gentleness my strong enforcement be:
In the which hope I blush, and hide my sword.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE SENIOR
linegroup.line: True is it that we have seen better days,
And have with holy bell been knoll'd to church
And sat at good men's feasts and wiped our eyes
Of drops that sacred pity hath engender'd:
And therefore sit you down in gentleness
And take upon command what help we have
That to your wanting may be minister'd.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Then but forbear your food a little while,
Whiles, like a doe, I go to find my fawn
And give it food. There is an old poor man,
Who after me hath many a weary step
Limp'd in pure love: till he be first sufficed,
Oppress'd with two weak evils, age and hunger,
I will not touch a bit.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE SENIOR
linegroup.line: Go find him out,
And we will nothing waste till you return.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: I thank ye; and be blest for your good comfort!

linegroup.speaker: DUKE SENIOR
linegroup.line: Thou seest we are not all alone unhappy:
This wide and universal theatre
Presents more woeful pageants than the scene
Wherein we play in.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: All the world's a stage,
And all the men and women merely players:
They have their exits and their entrances;
And one man in his time plays many parts,
His acts being seven ages. At first the infant,
Mewling and puking in the nurse's arms.
And then the whining school-boy, with his satchel
And shining morning face, creeping like snail
Unwillingly to school. And then the lover,
Sighing like furnace, with a woeful ballad
Made to his mistress' eyebrow. Then a soldier,
Full of strange oaths and bearded like the pard,
Jealous in honour, sudden and quick in quarrel,
Seeking the bubble reputation
Even in the cannon's mouth. And then the justice,
In fair round belly with good capon lined,
With eyes severe and beard of formal cut,
Full of wise saws and modern instances;
And so he plays his part. The sixth age shifts
Into the lean and slipper'd pantaloon,
With spectacles on nose and pouch on side,
His youthful hose, well saved, a world too wide
For his shrunk shank; and his big manly voice,
Turning again toward childish treble, pipes
And whistles in his sound. Last scene of all,
That ends this strange eventful history,
Is second childishness and mere oblivion,
Sans teeth, sans eyes, sans taste, sans everything.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE SENIOR
linegroup.line: Welcome. Set down your venerable burthen,
And let him feed.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: I thank you most for him.

linegroup.speaker: ADAM
linegroup.line: So had you need:
I scarce can speak to thank you for myself.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE SENIOR
linegroup.line: Welcome; fall to: I will not trouble you
As yet, to question you about your fortunes.
Give us some music; and, good cousin, sing.

linegroup.speaker: AMIENS
linegroup.line: Blow, blow, thou winter wind.
Thou art not so unkind
As man's ingratitude;
Thy tooth is not so keen,
Because thou art not seen,
Although thy breath be rude.
Heigh-ho! sing, heigh-ho! unto the green holly:
Most friendship is feigning, most loving mere folly:
Then, heigh-ho, the holly!
This life is most jolly.
Freeze, freeze, thou bitter sky,
That dost not bite so nigh
As benefits forgot:
Though thou the waters warp,
Thy sting is not so sharp
As friend remember'd not.
Heigh-ho! sing, &c.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE SENIOR
linegroup.line: If that you were the good Sir Rowland's son,
As you have whisper'd faithfully you were,
And as mine eye doth his effigies witness
Most truly limn'd and living in your face,
Be truly welcome hither: I am the duke
That loved your father: the residue of your fortune,
Go to my cave and tell me. Good old man,
Thou art right welcome as thy master is.
Support him by the arm. Give me your hand,
And let me all your fortunes understand.

section.title: SCENE I. A room in the palace.
section.para: Enter DUKE FREDERICK, Lords, and OLIVER

linegroup.speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
linegroup.line: Not see him since? Sir, sir, that cannot be:
But were I not the better part made mercy,
I should not seek an absent argument
Of my revenge, thou present. But look to it:
Find out thy brother, wheresoe'er he is;
Seek him with candle; bring him dead or living
Within this twelvemonth, or turn thou no more
To seek a living in our territory.
Thy lands and all things that thou dost call thine
Worth seizure do we seize into our hands,
Till thou canst quit thee by thy brothers mouth
Of what we think against thee.

linegroup.speaker: OLIVER
linegroup.line: O that your highness knew my heart in this!
I never loved my brother in my life.

linegroup.speaker: DUKE FREDERICK
linegroup.line: More villain thou. Well, push him out of doors;
And let my officers of such a nature
Make an extent upon his house and lands:
Do this expediently and turn him going.

section.title: SCENE II. The forest.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Hang there, my verse, in witness of my love:
And thou, thrice-crowned queen of night, survey
With thy chaste eye, from thy pale sphere above,
Thy huntress' name that my full life doth sway.
O Rosalind! these trees shall be my books
And in their barks my thoughts I'll character;
That every eye which in this forest looks
Shall see thy virtue witness'd every where.
Run, run, Orlando; carve on every tree
The fair, the chaste and unexpressive she.

linegroup.speaker: CORIN
linegroup.line: And how like you this shepherd's life, Master Touchstone?

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: Truly, shepherd, in respect of itself, it is a good
life, but in respect that it is a shepherd's life,
it is naught. In respect that it is solitary, I
like it very well; but in respect that it is
private, it is a very vile life. Now, in respect it
is in the fields, it pleaseth me well; but in
respect it is not in the court, it is tedious. As
is it a spare life, look you, it fits my humour well;
but as there is no more plenty in it, it goes much
against my stomach. Hast any philosophy in thee, shepherd?

linegroup.speaker: CORIN
linegroup.line: No more but that I know the more one sickens the
worse at ease he is; and that he that wants money,
means and content is without three good friends;
that the property of rain is to wet and fire to
burn; that good pasture makes fat sheep, and that a
great cause of the night is lack of the sun; that
he that hath learned no wit by nature nor art may
complain of good breeding or comes of a very dull kindred.

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: Such a one is a natural philosopher. Wast ever in
court, shepherd?

linegroup.speaker: CORIN
linegroup.line: No, truly.

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: Then thou art damned.

linegroup.speaker: CORIN
linegroup.line: Nay, I hope.

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: Truly, thou art damned like an ill-roasted egg, all
on one side.

linegroup.speaker: CORIN
linegroup.line: For not being at court? Your reason.

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: Why, if thou never wast at court, thou never sawest
good manners; if thou never sawest good manners,
then thy manners must be wicked; and wickedness is
sin, and sin is damnation. Thou art in a parlous
state, shepherd.

linegroup.speaker: CORIN
linegroup.line: Not a whit, Touchstone: those that are good manners
at the court are as ridiculous in the country as the
behavior of the country is most mockable at the
court. You told me you salute not at the court, but
you kiss your hands: that courtesy would be
uncleanly, if courtiers were shepherds.

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: Instance, briefly; come, instance.

linegroup.speaker: CORIN
linegroup.line: Why, we are still handling our ewes, and their
fells, you know, are greasy.

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: Why, do not your courtier's hands sweat? and is not
the grease of a mutton as wholesome as the sweat of
a man? Shallow, shallow. A better instance, I say; come.

linegroup.speaker: CORIN
linegroup.line: Besides, our hands are hard.

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: Your lips will feel them the sooner. Shallow again.
A more sounder instance, come.

linegroup.speaker: CORIN
linegroup.line: And they are often tarred over with the surgery of
our sheep: and would you have us kiss tar? The
courtier's hands are perfumed with civet.

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: Most shallow man! thou worms-meat, in respect of a
good piece of flesh indeed! Learn of the wise, and
perpend: civet is of a baser birth than tar, the
very uncleanly flux of a cat. Mend the instance, shepherd.

linegroup.speaker: CORIN
linegroup.line: You have too courtly a wit for me: I'll rest.

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: Wilt thou rest damned? God help thee, shallow man!
God make incision in thee! thou art raw.

linegroup.speaker: CORIN
linegroup.line: Sir, I am a true labourer: I earn that I eat, get
that I wear, owe no man hate, envy no man's
happiness, glad of other men's good, content with my
harm, and the greatest of my pride is to see my ewes
graze and my lambs suck.

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: That is another simple sin in you, to bring the ewes
and the rams together and to offer to get your
living by the copulation of cattle; to be bawd to a
bell-wether, and to betray a she-lamb of a
twelvemonth to a crooked-pated, old, cuckoldly ram,
out of all reasonable match. If thou beest not
damned for this, the devil himself will have no
shepherds; I cannot see else how thou shouldst
'scape.

linegroup.speaker: CORIN
linegroup.line: Here comes young Master Ganymede, my new mistress's brother.

section.para: Enter ROSALIND, with a paper, reading

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: From the east to western Ind,
No jewel is like Rosalind.
Her worth, being mounted on the wind,
Through all the world bears Rosalind.
All the pictures fairest lined
Are but black to Rosalind.
Let no fair be kept in mind
But the fair of Rosalind.

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: I'll rhyme you so eight years together, dinners and
suppers and sleeping-hours excepted: it is the
right butter-women's rank to market.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Out, fool!

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: For a taste:
If a hart do lack a hind,
Let him seek out Rosalind.
If the cat will after kind,
So be sure will Rosalind.
Winter garments must be lined,
So must slender Rosalind.
They that reap must sheaf and bind;
Then to cart with Rosalind.
Sweetest nut hath sourest rind,
Such a nut is Rosalind.
He that sweetest rose will find
Must find love's prick and Rosalind.
This is the very false gallop of verses: why do you
infect yourself with them?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Peace, you dull fool! I found them on a tree.

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: Truly, the tree yields bad fruit.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: I'll graff it with you, and then I shall graff it
with a medlar: then it will be the earliest fruit
i' the country; for you'll be rotten ere you be half
ripe, and that's the right virtue of the medlar.

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: You have said; but whether wisely or no, let the
forest judge.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Peace! Here comes my sister, reading: stand aside.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Why should this a desert be?
For it is unpeopled? No:
Tongues I'll hang on every tree,
That shall civil sayings show:
Some, how brief the life of man
Runs his erring pilgrimage,
That the stretching of a span
Buckles in his sum of age;
Some, of violated vows
'Twixt the souls of friend and friend:
But upon the fairest boughs,
Or at every sentence end,
Will I Rosalinda write,
Teaching all that read to know
The quintessence of every sprite
Heaven would in little show.
Therefore Heaven Nature charged
That one body should be fill'd
With all graces wide-enlarged:
Nature presently distill'd
Helen's cheek, but not her heart,
Cleopatra's majesty,
Atalanta's better part,
Sad Lucretia's modesty.
Thus Rosalind of many parts
By heavenly synod was devised,
Of many faces, eyes and hearts,
To have the touches dearest prized.
Heaven would that she these gifts should have,
And I to live and die her slave.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: O most gentle pulpiter! what tedious homily of love
have you wearied your parishioners withal, and never
cried 'Have patience, good people!'

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: How now! back, friends! Shepherd, go off a little.
Go with him, sirrah.

linegroup.speaker: TOUCHSTONE
linegroup.line: Come, shepherd, let us make an honourable retreat;
though not with bag and baggage, yet with scrip and scrippage.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Didst thou hear these verses?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: O, yes, I heard them all, and more too; for some of
them had in them more feet than the verses would bear.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: That's no matter: the feet might bear the verses.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Ay, but the feet were lame and could not bear
themselves without the verse and therefore stood
lamely in the verse.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: But didst thou hear without wondering how thy name
should be hanged and carved upon these trees?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: I was seven of the nine days out of the wonder
before you came; for look here what I found on a
palm-tree. I was never so be-rhymed since
Pythagoras' time, that I was an Irish rat, which I
can hardly remember.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Trow you who hath done this?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Is it a man?

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: And a chain, that you once wore, about his neck.
Change you colour?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: I prithee, who?

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: O Lord, Lord! it is a hard matter for friends to
meet; but mountains may be removed with earthquakes
and so encounter.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Nay, but who is it?

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Is it possible?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Nay, I prithee now with most petitionary vehemence,
tell me who it is.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: O wonderful, wonderful, and most wonderful
wonderful! and yet again wonderful, and after that,
out of all hooping!

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Good my complexion! dost thou think, though I am
caparisoned like a man, I have a doublet and hose in
my disposition? One inch of delay more is a
South-sea of discovery; I prithee, tell me who is it
quickly, and speak apace. I would thou couldst
stammer, that thou mightst pour this concealed man
out of thy mouth, as wine comes out of a narrow-
mouthed bottle, either too much at once, or none at
all. I prithee, take the cork out of thy mouth that
may drink thy tidings.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: So you may put a man in your belly.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Is he of God's making? What manner of man? Is his
head worth a hat, or his chin worth a beard?

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Nay, he hath but a little beard.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Why, God will send more, if the man will be
thankful: let me stay the growth of his beard, if
thou delay me not the knowledge of his chin.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: It is young Orlando, that tripped up the wrestler's
heels and your heart both in an instant.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Nay, but the devil take mocking: speak, sad brow and
true maid.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: I' faith, coz, 'tis he.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Orlando?

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Orlando.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Alas the day! what shall I do with my doublet and
hose? What did he when thou sawest him? What said
he? How looked he? Wherein went he? What makes
him here? Did he ask for me? Where remains he?
How parted he with thee? and when shalt thou see
him again? Answer me in one word.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: You must borrow me Gargantua's mouth first: 'tis a
word too great for any mouth of this age's size. To
say ay and no to these particulars is more than to
answer in a catechism.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: But doth he know that I am in this forest and in
man's apparel? Looks he as freshly as he did the
day he wrestled?

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: It is as easy to count atomies as to resolve the
propositions of a lover; but take a taste of my
finding him, and relish it with good observance.
I found him under a tree, like a dropped acorn.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: It may well be called Jove's tree, when it drops
forth such fruit.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Give me audience, good madam.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Proceed.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: There lay he, stretched along, like a wounded knight.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Though it be pity to see such a sight, it well
becomes the ground.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: Cry 'holla' to thy tongue, I prithee; it curvets
unseasonably. He was furnished like a hunter.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: O, ominous! he comes to kill my heart.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: I would sing my song without a burden: thou bringest
me out of tune.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Do you not know I am a woman? when I think, I must
speak. Sweet, say on.

linegroup.speaker: CELIA
linegroup.line: You bring me out. Soft! comes he not here?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: 'Tis he: slink by, and note him.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: I thank you for your company; but, good faith, I had
as lief have been myself alone.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: And so had I; but yet, for fashion sake, I thank you
too for your society.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: God be wi' you: let's meet as little as we can.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: I do desire we may be better strangers.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: I pray you, mar no more trees with writing
love-songs in their barks.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: I pray you, mar no more of my verses with reading
them ill-favouredly.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: Rosalind is your love's name?

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Yes, just.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: I do not like her name.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: There was no thought of pleasing you when she was
christened.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: What stature is she of?

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Just as high as my heart.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: You are full of pretty answers. Have you not been
acquainted with goldsmiths' wives, and conned them
out of rings?

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Not so; but I answer you right painted cloth, from
whence you have studied your questions.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: You have a nimble wit: I think 'twas made of
Atalanta's heels. Will you sit down with me? and
we two will rail against our mistress the world and
all our misery.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: I will chide no breather in the world but myself,
against whom I know most faults.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: The worst fault you have is to be in love.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: 'Tis a fault I will not change for your best virtue.
I am weary of you.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: By my troth, I was seeking for a fool when I found
you.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: He is drowned in the brook: look but in, and you
shall see him.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: There I shall see mine own figure.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Which I take to be either a fool or a cipher.

linegroup.speaker: JAQUES
linegroup.line: I'll tarry no longer with you: farewell, good
Signior Love.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: I am glad of your departure: adieu, good Monsieur
Melancholy.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Aside to CELIA I will speak to him, like a saucy
lackey and under that habit play the knave with him.
Do you hear, forester?

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Very well: what would you?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: I pray you, what is't o'clock?

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: You should ask me what time o' day: there's no clock
in the forest.

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Then there is no true lover in the forest; else
sighing every minute and groaning every hour would
detect the lazy foot of Time as well as a clock.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: And why not the swift foot of Time? had not that
been as proper?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: By no means, sir: Time travels in divers paces with
divers persons. I'll tell you who Time ambles
withal, who Time trots withal, who Time gallops
withal and who he stands still withal.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: I prithee, who doth he trot withal?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: Marry, he trots hard with a young maid between the
contract of her marriage and the day it is
solemnized: if the interim be but a se'nnight,
Time's pace is so hard that it seems the length of
seven year.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Who ambles Time withal?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: With a priest that lacks Latin and a rich man that
hath not the gout, for the one sleeps easily because
he cannot study, and the other lives merrily because
he feels no pain, the one lacking the burden of lean
and wasteful learning, the other knowing no burden
of heavy tedious penury; these Time ambles withal.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Who doth he gallop withal?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: With a thief to the gallows, for though he go as
softly as foot can fall, he thinks himself too soon there.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Who stays it still withal?

linegroup.speaker: ROSALIND
linegroup.line: With lawyers in the vacation, for they sleep between
term and term and then they perceive not how Time moves.

linegroup.speaker: ORLANDO
linegroup.line: Where dwell you, pretty youth?
